comment_text.mn33:2.1: Since organizing teachings by number is the hallmark of the Aṅguttara Nikāya, it comes as no surprise to see this pattern repeated in the Book of the Elevens at AN 11.17, AN 11.22–29, and AN 11.502–981.
comment_text.mn33:2.3: “Knowing form” (rūpaññū ) means being able to keep track of the herd by reckoning or recognizing them. A better translation would be “appearance”, but I use “form” for consistency. | “Ford” (tittha) is a way across the river. | “Spreads smoke” (dhūmaṁ kattā) is the traditional practice of warding off flies and other pests by burning cow dung, etc. | “Satisfy” (pīta) is less literal than “drink”, but clarifies the simile later on.
comment_text.mn33:9.1: A tittha (“ford”) is a path to salvation, usually used of non-Buddhist religions, whose founders are “ford-makers” (titthakāra).
comment_text.mn33:9.2: “Inheritors of the heritage” is āgatāgamā, where āgama means “what has come down”, namely the scriptural heritage. Āgama is a synonym for nikāya in the sense of “collection of scripture”. | The “outlines” (mātikā, literally “matrix”) are the summary outlines of topics that served as seeds for the development of Abhidhamma. DN 16:3.50.5 features one of the earliest of such lists, the 37 path factors that the Buddha “taught from his own direct knowledge”. These serve as outline for the section on the path in the Saṁyutta, from where they were adopted in various Abhidhamma texts such as the Vibhaṅga.
comment_text.mn33:10.2: This plays on the similarity of pīta (“to have drunk, to have found satisfaction”) and pīti (“rapture, joy”); see also Snp 2.3:5.1.

root_text.mn33:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn33:2.1: “Ekādasahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako abhabbo gogaṇaṁ pariharituṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
root_text.mn33:2.3: Idha, bhikkhave, gopālako na rūpaññū hoti, na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, na āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti, na vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti, na dhūmaṁ kattā hoti, na titthaṁ jānāti, na pītaṁ jānāti, na vīthiṁ jānāti, na gocarakusalo hoti anavasesadohī ca hoti. Ye te usabhā gopitaro gopariṇāyakā te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
root_text.mn33:2.4: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako abhabbo gogaṇaṁ pariharituṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
root_text.mn33:3.1: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu abhabbo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjituṁ.
root_text.mn33:3.3: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti, na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, na āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti, na vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti, na dhūmaṁ kattā hoti, na titthaṁ jānāti, na pītaṁ jānāti, na vīthiṁ jānāti, na gocarakusalo hoti, anavasesadohī ca hoti. Ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
root_text.mn33:4.1: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti?
root_text.mn33:4.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yaṁ kiñci rūpaṁ sabbaṁ rūpaṁ ‘cattāri mahābhūtāni, catunnañca mahābhūtānaṁ upādāyarūpan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
root_text.mn33:4.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti.
root_text.mn33:5.1: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti?
root_text.mn33:5.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘kammalakkhaṇo bālo, kammalakkhaṇo paṇḍito’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
root_text.mn33:5.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti.
root_text.mn33:6.1: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti?
root_text.mn33:6.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṁ kāmavitakkaṁ adhivāseti, nappajahati na vinodeti na byantī karoti na anabhāvaṁ gameti. Uppannaṁ byāpādavitakkaṁ …pe… uppannaṁ vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ …pe… uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme adhivāseti, nappajahati na vinodeti na byantī karoti na anabhāvaṁ gameti.
root_text.mn33:6.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti.
root_text.mn33:7.1: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti?
root_text.mn33:7.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā nimittaggāhī hoti anubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn33:7.3: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya na paṭipajjati, na rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye na saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn33:7.8: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya nimittaggāhī hoti anubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn33:7.9: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya na paṭipajjati, na rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye na saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn33:7.10: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti.
root_text.mn33:8.1: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na dhūmaṁ kattā hoti?
root_text.mn33:8.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ na vitthārena paresaṁ desetā hoti.
root_text.mn33:8.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na dhūmaṁ kattā hoti.
root_text.mn33:9.1: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na titthaṁ jānāti?
root_text.mn33:9.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū bahussutā āgatāgamā dhammadharā vinayadharā mātikādharā, te kālena kālaṁ upasaṅkamitvā na paripucchati, na paripañhati:
root_text.mn33:9.5: Tassa te āyasmanto avivaṭañceva na vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca na uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhānīyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṁ na paṭivinodenti.

root_text.mn33:10.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye desiyamāne na labhati atthavedaṁ, na labhati dhammavedaṁ, na labhati dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ pāmojjaṁ.

translation_text.mn33:0.2: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd
translation_text.mn33:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn33:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn33:2.1: “Mendicants, a cowherd with eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
translation_text.mn33:2.3: It’s when a cowherd doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in ranges, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and captains of the herd.
translation_text.mn33:2.4: A cowherd with these eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
translation_text.mn33:3.1: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn33:3.3: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in ranges, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn33:4.1: And how does a mendicant not know form?
translation_text.mn33:4.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand that all form is the four principal states, or form derived from the four principal states.
translation_text.mn33:4.3: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know form.
translation_text.mn33:5.1: And how is a mendicant not skilled in characteristics?
translation_text.mn33:5.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t understand that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds.
translation_text.mn33:5.3: That’s how a mendicant isn’t skilled in characteristics.
translation_text.mn33:6.1: And how does a mendicant not pick out flies’ eggs?
translation_text.mn33:6.2: It’s when a mendicant tolerates a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen. They tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen. They don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
translation_text.mn33:6.3: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs.
translation_text.mn33:7.1: And how does a mendicant not dress wounds?
translation_text.mn33:7.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn33:7.3: Since the faculty of sight is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of sight, and they don’t achieve its restraint.
translation_text.mn33:7.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn33:7.5: smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn33:7.6: taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn33:7.7: feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn33:7.8: know an idea with their mind, they get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn33:7.9: Since the faculty of the mind is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of the mind, and they don’t achieve its restraint.
translation_text.mn33:7.10: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t dress wounds.
translation_text.mn33:8.1: And how does a mendicant not spread smoke?
translation_text.mn33:8.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t teach others the Dhamma in detail as they learned and memorized it.
translation_text.mn33:8.3: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t spread smoke.
translation_text.mn33:9.1: And how does a mendicant not know the ford?
translation_text.mn33:9.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t from time to time go up to those mendicants who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—and ask them questions:
translation_text.mn33:9.5: Those venerables don’t reveal what is hidden, clarify what is unclear, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.
translation_text.mn33:9.6: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know the ford.
translation_text.mn33:10.1: And how does a mendicant not know satisfaction?
translation_text.mn33:10.2: It’s when a mendicant, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, finds no inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds no joy connected with the teaching.
translation_text.mn33:10.3: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know satisfaction.
translation_text.mn33:11.1: And how does a mendicant not know the trail?
translation_text.mn33:11.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the noble eightfold path.
translation_text.mn33:11.3: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know the trail.
translation_text.mn33:12.1: And how is a mendicant not skilled in ranges?
translation_text.mn33:12.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
translation_text.mn33:12.3: That’s how a mendicant is not skilled in ranges.
translation_text.mn33:13.1: And how does a mendicant milk dry?
translation_text.mn33:13.2: It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, and that mendicant doesn’t know moderation in accepting.
translation_text.mn33:13.3: That’s how a mendicant milks dry.
translation_text.mn33:14.1: And how does a mendicant not show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?
translation_text.mn33:14.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t consistently treat senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
translation_text.mn33:14.5: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn33:14.6: A mendicant with these eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn33:15.1: A cowherd with eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
translation_text.mn33:15.3: It’s when a cowherd knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, spreads smoke, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in ranges, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and captains of the herd.
translation_text.mn33:15.4: A cowherd with these eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
translation_text.mn33:16.1: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn33:16.3: It’s when a mendicant knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, spreads smoke, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in ranges, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn33:17.1: And how does a mendicant know form?
translation_text.mn33:17.2: It’s when a mendicant truly understands that all form is the four principal states, or form derived from the four principal states.
translation_text.mn33:17.3: That’s how a mendicant knows form.
translation_text.mn33:18.1: And how is a mendicant skilled in characteristics?
translation_text.mn33:18.2: It’s when a mendicant understands that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds.
translation_text.mn33:18.3: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in characteristics.
translation_text.mn33:19.1: And how does a mendicant pick out flies’ eggs?
translation_text.mn33:19.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
translation_text.mn33:19.3: That’s how a mendicant picks out flies’ eggs.
translation_text.mn33:20.1: And how does a mendicant dress wounds?
translation_text.mn33:20.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn33:20.3: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn33:20.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn33:20.5: smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn33:20.6: taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn33:20.7: feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn33:20.8: know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn33:20.9: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn33:20.10: That’s how a mendicant dresses wounds.
translation_text.mn33:21.1: And how does a mendicant spread smoke?
translation_text.mn33:21.2: It’s when a mendicant teaches others the Dhamma in detail as they learned and memorized it.
translation_text.mn33:21.3: That’s how a mendicant spreads smoke.
translation_text.mn33:22.1: And how does a mendicant know the ford?
translation_text.mn33:22.2: It’s when from time to time a mendicant goes up to those mendicants who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—and asks them questions:
translation_text.mn33:22.5: Those venerables reveal what is hidden, clarify what is unclear, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.
translation_text.mn33:22.6: That’s how a mendicant knows the ford.
translation_text.mn33:23.1: And how does a mendicant know satisfaction?
translation_text.mn33:23.2: It’s when a mendicant, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching.
translation_text.mn33:23.3: That’s how a mendicant knows satisfaction.
translation_text.mn33:24.1: And how does a mendicant know the trail?
translation_text.mn33:24.2: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the noble eightfold path.
translation_text.mn33:24.3: That’s how a mendicant knows the trail.
translation_text.mn33:25.1: And how is a mendicant skilled in ranges?
translation_text.mn33:25.2: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
translation_text.mn33:25.3: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in ranges.
translation_text.mn33:26.1: And how does a mendicant not milk dry?
translation_text.mn33:26.2: It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick,
translation_text.mn33:26.3: and that mendicant knows moderation in accepting.
translation_text.mn33:26.4: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t milk dry.
translation_text.mn33:27.1: And how does a mendicant show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?
translation_text.mn33:27.2: It’s when a mendicant consistently treats senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
translation_text.mn33:27.5: That’s how a mendicant shows extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn33:27.6: A mendicant with these eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.”
translation_text.mn33:27.7: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn33:27.8: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn33:2.1: phātiṁ kātuṁ → phātikattuṁ (bj, pts1ed); phātikātuṁ (sya-all, km)
